name: NewYorker
text: In “Juneteenth,” one character makes a frame for the understanding of the holiday, by exhorting worshippers to approach it as something like Passover—a day of deliverance on which to tell stories that keep history alive in memory. https://t.co/YVqA1BT5cK

name: NewYorker
text: The closer an apple is to rot, the more rot it spreads—one spoiling apple speeds the rot of every apple it touches, and even of ones it doesn’t touch. https://t.co/OrgvFk1A4H

name: NewYorker
text: “This man’s life will not be in vain,” one protester said, at the site of George Floyd’s murder. “This is going worldwide. The entire world is hearing us.” https://t.co/qlzDZgHdg7
